Timberborn stands out as an excellent game about building dams and managing water to support a beaver colony. It keeps the theme consistently well, from the aesthetic to the gameplay focused on drought cycles, water flow, and hydraulic control. The only detail that breaks the coherence a bit is the use of horsepower as a power unit: a beaver having 50 hp doesn‚Äôt really make sense, and it would be interesting to adopt something more fitting for the game‚Äôs universe. Apart from that, it‚Äôs a very well-crafted, original, and memorable experience within the genre.

Icarus is a really solid survival game. The graphics are amazing, environments look great and exploring the map never gets old. Gameplay feels good and rewarding, especially in co-op, but it also works well solo.

What really stands out is the constant updates. The devs keep pushing new content, fixes and improvements, and it‚Äôs clear they actually listen to the community. The game today is much better than at launch and keeps evolving.

It can be tough and unforgiving at times, but that‚Äôs part of the appeal. If you like survival, crafting and long-term progression, this game will easily keep you busy for a long time.

Worth it.

[u]‚Äé[b]English:[/b][/u]

Stunning presentation. Arrakis arrives with reference-grade fidelity: dunes with rippling physics, wind-carved ridges, heat-haze mirages, and volumetric lighting that turns sandstorms and sunsets into living tableaux. Texture work on stillsuits, ornithopters, and machinery is immaculate, and the soundscape (whispering sand, distant worms, turbine whine) seals the immersion.

Addictive farming loop. The explore ‚Üí extract ‚Üí process ‚Üí upgrade cycle is elegant and compulsive. You spot spice blooms, deploy compact rigs, time carryall pickups between storm fronts, and manage heat, water, and weight to stretch every sortie. Upgrades matter‚Äîfilters extend expeditions, gliders and boots refine dune ‚Äúparkour,‚Äù and extraction modules boost yield without trivialising the challenge.

Tension and tactics. Risk‚Äìreward is razor-sharp: longer harvests amplify your sand signature and worm threat, forcing real decisions‚Äîcash in now or risk ‚Äúone more sweep‚Äù? Route planning, payload balance, and terrain reading add gratifying logistics.

Combat and stealth in service of survival. Responsive tools‚Äîsand lures, light precision weapons, swift evasions‚Äîenable clean, purposeful engagements that protect the operation rather than distract from it.

Verdict: a visually superb, mechanically tight experience where beauty, pressure, and progression interlock. Farming is thrilling, never grindy; every decision counts‚Äîand every grain of spice feels earned. I‚Äôve seen the films and, without doubt, this game kept my love for the saga alive‚Äîit's strikingly faithful to the look, tone, and detail of the universe.‚Äé

[u]‚Äé[b]Portugu√™s:[/b][/u]

Apresenta√ß√£o deslumbrante. Arrakis surge com fidelidade de refer√™ncia: dunas com f√≠sica ondulante, cristas esculpidas pelo vento, miragens de calor e ilumina√ß√£o volum√©trica que transforma tempestades e pores do sol em aut√™nticos quadros vivos. A textura dos stillsuits, dos ornit√≥pteros e da maquinaria √© irrepreens√≠vel, e a paisagem sonora (areia a sussurrar, vermes ao longe, turbinas em esfor√ßo) fecha a imers√£o com chave de ouro.

Loop de ‚Äúfarm‚Äù viciante. O ciclo explorar ‚Üí extrair ‚Üí processar ‚Üí melhorar √© elegante e compulsivo. Identificamos focos de especiaria, montamos rigs compactos, cronometramos o carryall entre frentes de tempestade e gerimos calor, √°gua e peso para esticar cada incurs√£o. As melhorias contam ‚Äî filtros prolongam expedi√ß√µes, planeadores e botas refinam o ‚Äúparkour‚Äù nas dunas, e m√≥dulos de extra√ß√£o aumentam o rendimento sem trivializar o desafio.

Tens√£o e t√°ctica. O risco‚Äìrecompensa √© afiado: colheitas mais longas amplificam a assinatura na areia e a amea√ßa dos vermes, impondo decis√µes reais ‚Äî encaixar agora ou arriscar ‚Äús√≥ mais uma varredura‚Äù? Planeamento de rotas, equil√≠brio de carga e leitura do terreno acrescentam uma log√≠stica gratificante.

Combate e stealth ao servi√ßo da sobreviv√™ncia. Ferramentas responsivas ‚Äî iscos de areia, armas leves e precisas, evas√µes r√°pidas ‚Äî permitem confrontos limpos e intencionais que protegem a opera√ß√£o em vez de a desviar.

Veredicto: um t√≠tulo visualmente soberbo e mecanicamente coeso, onde beleza, press√£o e progress√£o se entrela√ßam. O ‚Äúfarm‚Äù √© empolgante, nunca repetitivo; cada decis√£o pesa ‚Äî e cada gr√£o de especiaria sabe a conquista. Vi os filmes e, sem d√∫vida, continuei a adorar a saga neste jogo ‚Äî est√° super id√™ntico e respeita a est√©tica, o tom e os detalhes do universo.

Dune: Awakening √© um jogo ambicioso, situado no ic√¥nico universo de Frank Herbert. A proposta de misturar sobreviv√™ncia, MMO e explora√ß√£o em mundo aberto √© ousada e tem enorme potencial ‚Äî mas ainda est√° longe de entregar tudo que promete.

Pontos positivos:
Ambiente fiel e imersivo: O deserto de Arrakis est√° bem representado, com visuais lindos, tempestades de areia atmosf√©ricas e uma sensa√ß√£o constante de perigo.

Progress√£o e crafting envolventes: O sistema de evolu√ß√£o do personagem e de fabrica√ß√£o de itens tem profundidade e incentiva a explora√ß√£o.

Customiza√ß√£o: Possibilidade de personalizar o personagem e adaptar estilos de jogo (combate, furtividade, explora√ß√£o).

Lore bem explorado: Para f√£s da franquia, h√° muitas refer√™ncias interessantes ao universo original de Dune.

Pontos negativos:
Performance irregular: Mesmo em m√°quinas potentes, ainda h√° travamentos, quedas de FPS e bugs gr√°ficos (como texturas serrilhadas e anima√ß√µes estranhas).

Falta de conte√∫do no endgame: Ap√≥s certo progresso, o jogo se torna repetitivo e ainda carece de conte√∫do robusto para jogadores mais avan√ßados.

Intera√ß√£o limitada no MMO: A ideia de mundo compartilhado √© boa, mas ainda n√£o √© bem aproveitada. As intera√ß√µes entre jogadores s√£o superficiais.

Economia mal balanceada: Algumas receitas e equipamentos exigem grind excessivo, prejudicando o ritmo do jogo.

Considera√ß√µes finais:
Dune: Awakening √© um jogo em constru√ß√£o. Ele tem uma base s√≥lida e uma ambienta√ß√£o cativante, mas precisa de mais otimiza√ß√£o, conte√∫dos adicionais e ajustes na jogabilidade. Se voc√™ √© f√£ do universo Dune ou gosta de jogos de sobreviv√™ncia em mundo aberto, pode valer a pena ‚Äî mas esteja ciente que o jogo ainda est√° em processo de matura√ß√£o.

[EN] I really enjoyed it, and playing with friends makes it even better. I almost recommend buying it, but with the following points I‚Äôm going to mention, it becomes difficult.

NEGATIVES
- In several situations, your character gets stuck braking (for example, when climbing, it keeps repeating the last meter).
- There are many bugs (in several cases they make you die, for example when you try to get into a vehicle and it doesn‚Äôt work, and then a worm comes and eats you).
- Sometimes you see spice and somehow it‚Äôs no longer there.
- Very repetitive, even the stations, caves, and other areas. It ends up being copy-paste.
- Sometimes, out of nowhere, you fall through the map.

THOSE THINGS ‚ÄúMhhhhhh‚Äù 
- In the Deep Desert, the storm (reset) would be more fun if it happened every 2 weeks instead of every week. Having to rebuild the base every week is a huge waste of time.
- In Hagga Basin it‚Äôs ridiculous when you can‚Äôt loot abandoned bases.
- There‚Äôs no ranking system for PVP at all‚Äînothing. If you go into PVP it‚Äôs just killing for no purpose or reward.
- The fights are‚Ä¶ mhhhh‚Ä¶ very disappointing (terribly awful).

Conclusion: I think the game becomes very repetitive, and I believe many of the bugs will not be fixed.

[h1]Review of Enshrouded after ~130 hours[/h1]

I bought Enshrouded almost two years ago and refunded it after about an hour and a half. At launch, the game was in a terrible state. It was full of bugs, performance issues, and gameplay problems to the point where it was almost unplayable. Looking back at the early Steam reviews, I was far from alone. The negative feedback at release was justified, and I was one of those players who walked away disappointed.

A few months later, I noticed that many fixes and updates had been released. I decided to give the game a second chance, bought it again, and played a bit more. It was clearly better, but the bad first impression was still there. I ended up leaving the game installed and untouched for a long time.

Fast forward to November and December, I was bored over the holidays and decided to finally give Enshrouded a proper try. This time, the experience was very different.

The game today is much better than what I originally played. It is stable, content-rich, and genuinely enjoyable. The world is massive, sometimes too massive. Exploration can feel exciting, but it can also become tiring because everything takes time. This is not a game you finish in a few evenings. If you aim for high completion, expect to spend dozens or even hundreds of hours.

In my case, I reached a point where I had completed most of the content available to me, but I also hit burnout. The grind is real.

This is not an easy game, especially for solo players. Progress often requires heavy farming, crafting, and repetition. Death is punishing, and losing your gear can feel brutal. There are settings and modifiers that can reduce this, and my honest recommendation is simple: use them.

If you try to play Enshrouded exactly as intended on normal settings, the game can become more frustrating than rewarding. Adjust the difficulty, tweak the world rules, and use mods if needed. Otherwise, you will spend too much time grinding for too little satisfaction.

There is no shame in playing on easier settings. Even with reduced difficulty, the game is still challenging. This is not a casual-friendly experience, especially in single player.

I strongly believe the game shines more in co-op. Playing with friends allows role splitting, shared progression, and smoother difficulty spikes. As a solo player, however, the experience can feel unbalanced. Some classes clearly have advantages over others, and the overall balance is not great.

Crafting and farming systems are well designed on paper, but they demand a lot of time. Eventually, that grind starts to eat away at the fun.

I like difficult games. I like completion. Even so, Enshrouded sometimes punishes the player in ways that feel unfair rather than challenging. Difficulty should test skill and planning, not patience.

[b]Final thoughts[/b]

Enshrouded today is a good game, and a huge improvement over its launch state. However, it is demanding, grind-heavy, and unforgiving, especially for solo players. If you approach it with the right expectations, adjust the difficulty, and play it your way, you can have a great time. If you don‚Äôt, the game can easily turn into a chore.

Once again i'm going to share my opinion as a portuguese, i played ETS1 as a kid and i love this game since that moment, so i was very excited when this DLC was announced. To be honest i was disapointed with the insignificance of Portugal, but i thought that time will bring us good updates, which was not what happened.
Portugal is a small country with around 10 million habitants, which bring us "small" representation in game communities. In this case a game with the name Euro Truck Simulator, should consider that Portugal have the oldest defined borders of Europe and the use of trucks as a cargo transport is well spread, being almost the only way of transport, because of the small railway system and the dimension of the country and cities/towns doesn't allow to have a lot of airports so airway cargo is impossible. 
Some towns may be insignificant to the game team, but have in mind the scale of the country, what in a lot of european countries is a small town in Portugal is a city.
Ending my defense of the importance of the importance of Portugal in this game, i will give some of my suggestions to add in this DLC: 
- The Lisbon dealership is in a town near Lisbon (but not Lisbon) called Vialonga, Vialonga is not part of Lisbon City but is parte of the Vila Franca de Xira Municipality. As mentioned the scale of country makes this relevant.
- North of the A28 resting area is Matosinhos Municipality, which would make sense to be a town in the map and not part fo Oporto
- There are 7 main cargo ports in Portugal (Sines, Leix√µes, Lisbon, Setubal, Figueira da Foz, Aveiro and Viana do Castelo) the cities around this should be developed because they have a lot of industry and cargo companies around. As the example of Aveiro, the Port of Aveiro is in a small city called Gafanha da Nazar√© (√çlhavo Municipality) that have a lot of chemistry industry around, near is the begging of the A25 highway that's already in the game, in the City of Aveiro there is a big company facilitie of special transports near a Renault Trucks Dealership and a paper industry near too and still on the A25 highway there is Albergaria-a-Velha which have a LOT of cargo transport companies and connects some important roads like the A1, A25 and A29 highways and the IC2. 
- Portugal have the longest nacional road (EN2)with 738,5km, passing throught a lot of relevant towns and connecting Portugal from the top North in a town named Chaves near Spain, to the South in Faro.
- Interior cities must be represent to, Portugal isn't just beach. Portugal have 18 districts so at least the city that's the district capital must be in the game.

I really hope that SCS develop Portugal, and see that Portugal means something in the europe transports.

A relaxing and exciting experience ‚Äì perfect for two players!

The Planet Crafter truly surprised me in the best way. It‚Äôs one of those games that, even with a slow pace, keeps you engaged for hours. The concept is simple yet incredibly immersive: transform a barren, lifeless planet into a habitable world, step by step, by exploring, gathering resources, and building automation.

I played with one other person, and I can confidently say that it‚Äôs an excellent game for a team of two. The co-op feels natural and well-paced ‚Äî there‚Äôs always something for each player to do, whether it‚Äôs building, exploring, or managing the ecosystem‚Äôs development.

It‚Äôs also a very inclusive game: no stress, no unnecessary combat, and designed to be accessible for both experienced players and those just looking to relax and explore at their own pace. Everything comes together to create a calm and soothing experience ‚Äî perfect for unwinding after a long day.

At the same time, as the planet slowly transforms through your efforts, there‚Äôs a real sense of excitement. Seeing the sky turn blue for the first time or watching greenery begin to grow where there was only dust is genuinely rewarding. Every bit of visual and gameplay progress feels earned and meaningful.

I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a peaceful, cooperative adventure with a satisfying sense of progression. The Planet Crafter is a true indie gem that deserves more attention.

It's an amazing game, but truly, it isn't finished, unlike what the 1.0 version would lead one to believe. I bought it in early access.

I played this game in the pre-release version and I'm already in love with it. Perfect game if you like medieval Europe theme, city building, battle simulation, economy management and more. All under one very well balanced game.

Some things that I wish to see in the final realease or with later updates or even DLC's (Yes, I don't mind paying a bit more to add more features to the game if the quality of those expansions match the base game):
-Supply chain management tools. To be able to control the production flow with a specialized menu for example and not having to rely on pressing the building on the map.
-More stats. Per building, industry, year, etc.
-Improved and bigger battles 
-Cavalary units
-Bigger map
-The Baron actually has a settlement in the map which I can see being developed and can conquer.
-More "Barons", make alliances and futher negociations
-Add rivers, sea, ponds... water in general
-Fog of war to instigate exploration along with the right unit for that task
-More complex development tree
-Currently conquering other region doesn't add much to my domain... I mean, it's like I have another city to build from scratch and it's not even related to the other settlements. I can't even cut trees if the trees are on the other side of the border.
-Add more food types, materials, supplies, etc...
-Add more farm animals like cattle, pigs, goats, etc.. and respective meat production facilities.
-More control on the set up of burgage plots. For example, being able to manually adjust the limits, distances, sizes if the house, extension and field.
-Currently it's possible to upgrade the residences and as they upgrade so does the looks of the building. I wish all the other building, industry, administration, etc. could do the same. Not only these building could provide better productivity or/and unlock certain products but also change the looks. This would avoid having only certain buildings with rooftile and a more modern look right next to wooden shacks with hay roofs.
-More cosmetic assets with possible effects on the happiness of the people.
-PLEASE! Make a good platform for modders. This game will stay perfect forever if it has a good modding community!

Some features that I really like so far:
-The idea to limit the develpment points per region is perfect! Making you plan in advance your specialization for each reason.
-The way you build burgage plots.
-The fact that you allocate families to a job and not the single individual. That gives a sense of realism to the game. It's actually accurate: for example, the of the family would 
-Graphics in general. Considering the wide range of zooming the game provides it's amazing how well it looks both in the close ups and in the map view. 
-Battles give a sense of purpose! The goal of other city builders is to increase population, treasury, or aesthetics... Having to defend ourselves gives a sense of purpose and makes the game more chalenging. And not only that but you will see, plan, and control the fight yourself.

I wrote all this coment in one go. It's possibly I might have forgotten some other idea. 
In general I really loved this game and wish to love it even more. I have big hopes for the final realease and the years to come.

An√°lise Cr√≠tica: Problemas de Balanceamento e Experi√™ncia de Usu√°rio em Jogos Competitivos
A sua experi√™ncia reflete uma cr√≠tica muito v√°lida que muitos jogadores enfrentam ao lidar com jogos competitivos online: matchmaking injusto, falta de suporte para aprendizado e aus√™ncia de ferramentas para mitigar frustra√ß√µes. Vamos analisar ponto a ponto os problemas levantados e explorar suas poss√≠veis causas e solu√ß√µes.

1. Matchmaking e Balanceamento
Um dos pilares de um jogo competitivo √© o balanceamento adequado das partidas. No entanto, enfrentar jogadores de n√≠vel muito superior (como no caso de um jogador Bronze II enfrentando Diamantes) quebra completamente a experi√™ncia de aprendizado e divers√£o.

2. Falta de Guias e Suporte ao Aprendizado
O aprendizado √© essencial em qualquer jogo competitivo. Sem tutoriais realmente significantes para a realidade do jogo competitivo, guias acess√≠veis ou uma comunidade ativa, novos jogadores ficam √† deriva, tentando descobrir sozinhos como melhorar.

3. Falta de Mitiga√ß√£o de Frustra√ß√µes
30 jogos perdidos sem ganhar 1 n√£o s√£o apenas um problema estat√≠stico; eles representam tempo perdido e uma experi√™ncia frustrante. Isso √© agravado pela aus√™ncia de op√ß√µes como reembolso de progresso ou sistemas que protejam jogadores em situa√ß√µes extremas.

4. O Impacto de 14 Horas Perdidas
Jogos s√£o uma forma de entretenimento e, idealmente, deveriam oferecer uma experi√™ncia prazerosa ou, no m√≠nimo, gratificante. Quando isso n√£o acontece, o jogador se sente desrespeitado, algo que pode manchar permanentemente sua percep√ß√£o sobre o jogo.

Conclus√£o
A minha frustra√ß√£o √© totalmente v√°lida. Um jogo competitivo que oferece um matchmaking desequilibrado, carece de guias de aprendizado e n√£o possui sistemas de mitiga√ß√£o para evitar experi√™ncias negativas est√° falhando em sua principal proposta: proporcionar divers√£o e um senso de progresso.

To me, it's a "great game, but...". Frostpunk is definitely in my top 3 favorite games, I have around 370h on it and I still enjoy it. FP2 is good, it takes the idea of FP and makes its own thing which is fine, you don't want to just copy and paste, I get it... But FP2 is just harder and gets more repetitive, and I don't feel like replaying the same map over and over again like I do with FP. I wish there was a more relaxed mode, the factions get kind of annoying and I wish there was a dictator mode where everyone would just do as I said and shut the f up. I'd like to focus on creating a map that is organized and with quality of life for its citizens, instead of catering to everyone's whim and frustrations that are more childish than anything most of the times. Again, FP2 is a great game, but... you know.

While is not the same as the first installment, this one is actually really good asweel like the predecessor. Frostpunk 1 focus more in micromanagement of your city while frostpunk 2 is more about macro. I really think that both games are a masterpiece in the genre and i enjoy them both for what they are. Really recomend FP2 awesome game.

Other than that, the music is still as awesome as the first Frostpunk, gameplay is even more engaging, it will make you dream about the game and how to beat it.

Long story, you should really buy the game, 11bit studios really deserve it.

After finally 100% this game, this has become my favourite game of the year. Solid and fun city-building, the political system gives decisions weight, the game looks good (but would be nice some more details when zooming in) and the music is as great as ever.

The biggest problems I had with the game were the performance (which they have been improving with updates) and how uninteresting exploring the Frostland has become (which probably will remain so).

I was really angered by how many of the negative reviews are dishonest or malicious:
[list]
[*]"The game is like a worse Cities: Skylines / Civilization": no, to whomever played these games knows they have very little in common except for superficial concepts.

[*]"It doesn't have a soul": disagree, this game definitely isn't a mass produced, safe, cheap sequel. There are many moral decisions to be made and YOU are the one who has to experience if the consequences are positive or negative INSTEAD of the game telling you that. Now, it is true that individual deaths are less impactful, but that is an unfortunate consequence of the bigger scale.

[*]"Some things should have more detail or the game needs more content": In comparison to the first game, the Endless Mode was planned from the beginning and the gameplay is much more suitable for it. At the end of the day, this is a midrange priced game, not a 70$ AAA game, and as such, expectations should be a little more modest.

[*]"This one is worse than the first": down to personal opinion, but disagree. The only aspect which is better in the previous game is the intimacy with the citizens and exploration. The gameplay is better, the story has much bigger reflection of your actions in later consequences, the game looks better, and the music, storytelling and ambience are on par to the first one.
[/list]

I loved the game it only needs a few optimisation improvements and some bug fixes, nothing that a few patches can't fix. I enjoyed how the devs wanted to make a Frostpunk 2, not a Frostpunk 1.5 like many people wish for. It is a game not afraid to innovate and it shows. Good job 11 Bit Studios

Very Positive: The graphics update so far look incredible and all else feels smooth and enjoyable.

Mixed feelings: Making Chiron into a himbo looking dude certainly feels like... a choice, though. Making him old makes him seem wise but now it looks like he just wants me to sit down with and talk about my feelings and the new pastery shop down the street. Also, Athena's new voice... doesn't really spark joy, you know? Gargarensis also seemed more evil and meaner in the original too because of his voice, now he sounds like a chain-smoking wannabe D&D bard... In terms of gameplay: I hate the fact that the spells/godpowers are paid by Faith, by Zeus's Bolt that is annoying, but the fact they are no longer one use makes up for it.

Negative: Some missions feel shorter (need to see if they actually *are* shorter) than in the original campaign and the maps in it also seem smaller and emptier (that one I am 90% sure is true cause I especially remember a lot more stuff to do in some maps). Also breaking down the HP of some importante lore-wise objects to "realistic"/"balanced" levels kinda made me feel sad and kinda destroyed the sense of urgency I used to have when the mission envolved stoping their destruction (a nitpick, really). 

Anyway, this entire review is probably way too biased and coloured by nostalgia, so ignore me and play this amazing game!
It's totally worth it, especially if you pick it up on sale.

Frostpunk came out of nowhere and completely blew me away. I'm usually pretty picky with city-builders, but this game isn't just about building; it's about surviving. And man, what a ride it is.

From the moment you start, the atmosphere grips you like the relentless frost itself. The visuals are stark, beautiful, and perfectly convey the bleak, desperate struggle of humanity against an apocalyptic winter. The details in the character models, the animations, and the way the city grows (or withers) under the constant threat of cold are just phenomenal. You feel the desperation of your people.

But it's the soundtrack that truly elevates Frostpunk to another level. It's haunting, melancholic, and utterly breathtaking. It swells with hope in moments of success and plunges into despair as conditions worsen, perfectly amplifying the emotional weight of every decision you make. Seriously, I've listened to the soundtrack on its own because it's that good.
great game

Finally had the guts and time to dive in. Bought it on a Steam sale, always had it on the library for a "rainy day". The confinment came, and here I went. Never needed to read so much! To look for on Youtube videos and tons of tutorials. It's university all over again! Very hard to learn. It's like a 2nd job. I don't have the time for job games, those days are over for me :( After mastering all the course plotting, all the docking, all the jumping, and many more hidden details (dozens of hours watching Youtube), it's kind of boring. It's interface is far from intuitive. I tried X3, and gave up for the same reason. The benefits it brings vs the hardwork, it's not worth it! I'm uninstalling. We had perfection back in 2003. It was called Freelancer. After watching No Man's Sky or even Star Citizen videos, now I know, there will never be another Freelancer.
Well, more than 100 hrs, so I think it's was a very good experience. Now, waiting for the new expansion.

Bought this due the Odyssey DLC that's coming out. The game is massive. There's plenty ways and paths you can follow to make quick money in-game. Everspace is a great space simulator with an interesting story.

The very thing that I think puts out some players, actually can work as an advantage to others - the run roguelike system.
On your first run you start the game with a couple of ships to choose from, a limited setup, and go into space not knowing your own name, with some coordinates on your head you must reach (a.k.a. your ship's A.I.).
The tutorial sets you up, and you are ready - to die miserably as soon as a few ships surround and obliterate you.
You then realize there's a "timer" on each level, and a few Okkar (alien) ships will show up to hunt you when you stay on the same level for too long.
And then the fun starts: every run you die, you also get a few more credits, upgrade your ship a bit more, get better, stronger, faster, and soon you are ready to take out huge ships while escaping continuous bursts of lasers.

The graphics look great, action is fast, and the chars you meet show personality - and that makes it even more engaging.
Sounds and voice's are also very good.
I played the game with the Encounters DLC, meaning the extra content, missions, chars, etc (which I also recommend).
Game and DLC will allow you to fly with 4 ships, and each one is a different experience, from a heavy gunship with the lowest manouverability but very damaging weapons, to a light scout with stealth technology. That's plenty of variety for anyone who decides to explore all that the game has to offer.

The game's really fun, and it's actually quite simple, but does require some patience so "start over" again and again... and beware, it takes a lot of time to complete.
On the other hand, being a run based game, it means you can just play a little at a while - if you can resist the urge to do "just one more run".


Highly recommended - great value for money (especially considering how cheap it gets on some promotions).

->Gr√°ficos que te far√£o questionar a realidade: At√© as formigas a carregar migalhas parecem reais! S√≥ falta mesmo poderes dar zoom e ver as bact√©rias nos passeios.
->Uma simula√ß√£o mais profunda que o po√ßo de S. Vicente: Desde a economia √† pol√≠tica, passando pela sa√∫de e educa√ß√£o, vais ter de gerir tudo nos m√≠nimos detalhes, como se fosses um polvo a tocar piano.
->Cidad√£os com mais personalidade que os comentadores da CMTV: Cada habitante da tua cidade tem a sua pr√≥pria vida, os seus sonhos e as suas queixas (que vais ter de aturar nas redes sociais da cidade).
